segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Welcome to the annual Defcon Convention. This meeting was held in exciting Las Vegas, Nevada from July 9th through the 11th, 1999.
Yeah, I'm real uncomfortable with this stuff that we've got going on.
Yeah, turn it down before we get in there.
Give me my cord over here.
Mr. Man, we want to give you, can you give us a mic test real quick?
Don't hang up on him, please.
Alright, give us a mic check.
Let's hear it for Dune Ingenuity.
Okay, first of all, I want to find out if Professor Man, do you have anything, some words that you want to say and start off with?
I guess you're going to be giving a lecture, or do you just want to go straight into taking questions?
I'm going to just give a lecture about, I'm going to give a sort of lecture to myself.
And instead of seeing me, you're going to be being me.
Okay, good. And just an FYI, it looks like we've got the video here that's frozen.
So is that something on your end, or is that us?
We have like a freeze frame here of you holding.
We'll be getting six or seven frames a second.
Okay, just a moment then, let's try and solve that.
You can bear with us for just one moment, Professor.
I heard of something called mediated reality.
It's a buzzword in the media. Do you know anything about that?
Or have you heard, is that what you're involved with?
Mediated reality is something that simply means using the computer to alter the perception of reality.
I see. And what exactly, what kind of, what do you mean when you say alter the perception of reality?
Well, the iPad device absorbs light that would otherwise enter an eye of the wearer
and modifies that light and then reconstructs that light to pass into the wearer's eye.
So a simple example of mediated reality is when you're walking around, somebody wants to communicate with you.
One way they can communicate is by altering your reality.
For example, by putting a note on something.
So you're walking along and you see a sort of message that is, or you might see,
you go to the grocery store and you see the milk rolling to remind you to buy it.
You're talking to these car salesmen and, you know, your wife at home maybe makes his nose go long
Excellent. What if your wife's on acid at the time?
Well, you might have some problems there, but I think the general idea of mediated reality
is to change the perception of reality so it's a little bit different than virtual reality or video games
in the sense that you still see as a baseline what is actually in the real world
and then you see that modified version of that.
Excellent. Again, I guess we're still trying to establish the video feed
and what I'd like to do, you know, normally we would save this until the end.
I was just going to take a few questions from some of the people in the crowd here.
I'd like to answer those and then once we get the video feed going,
we'll let them see what we're talking about here.
So, let me see, how about you in front here?
What type of irresponsible uses do you see for this type of technology, professor?
I think like advertising, that type of thing.
One of the things that I try to do is design filters to filter out advertising
so that when you're walking around you can filter out real world spam.
You know, already we have spam in the real world such as billboards and things like that.
So, what I envision is that the mediated reality can be used to filter out the spam.
He asked, is the eye piece that you were speaking about, is that an implant,
is that an intrusive type of technology or is this something that you simply wear?
The current embodiments of eye cap technology, many of them are non-invasive
so that it's not necessary to modify the body in order to obtain an eye cap.
I see. Let me take another question here.
The question was, can you describe any existing types of this technology that are intrusive?
Or invasive, I guess that's what you put it.
I guess it depends on how invasive, whether things like electrodes and connections and things like that
The most useful technology I believe now is something that is totally a surface phenomena
so that it doesn't have to involve any solid connection to the body that might be disruptive.
That's what we got out there.
Yeah, I guess there's the delay problem and that's one of the reasons
the early embodiments of the reality mediator, I did the processing on the body
so I climbed up on the roof of the tallest building in the city and put the antennas there
and then I had a microwave down to the roof of the building and everything
and then I ran it out from there into various computers, one of which was an SGI reality engine
and several other processors so that it could keep up with the processing rate.
A big problem is processing rate and keeping up with the processing rate
so the other approach we're taking now is to build a big cluster with 64 processors
in a kind of clothing-based thing with 64 computers on it
that you can wear underneath a shirt or something like that.
Yeah, that's basically what it is.
Ordinarily, in my old rigs, I would be wearing 8 or 9 computers
and fairly fast video processing engines
but I think the Vail cluster will be the right approach to getting enough compute power
to really make the delay tolerable.
Okay, now let me take somebody in the back here.
There's a guy back here, the guy in the white shirt.
Yeah, I have a question about the hardware you're wearing.
The question was, can you describe the hardware you're wearing at the moment?
The hardware I'm wearing is a special purpose video processing engine
and then the whole infrastructure for it is a Linux-based computer
that will be running the Linux operating system
and communicating part of the hardware-based tool to a chip with the processing engine.
Just a moment before we continue.
Apparently, the guess is that somebody must have really wanted to see Jericho's top
because we're being smurfed from the outside.
The DOS attack is coming from that side.
Unfortunately, we have some people with pretty juvenile mentalities
so that's what we're dealing with.
So, what we're going to do is, I guess, continue the Q&A
until we can try to establish something or until the DOS stops
and we're just going to keep working with it.
So, there was a person in front who had one.
Yeah, I was going to ask you a question about glass and mirrors.
She said, what kind of specific problems are you thinking about?
The question was, do you have problems with glass mirrors
The processing engine just processes the light that comes in
so mirror-like surfaces haven't particularly been a problem.
The question was, what type of processors?
Do you have a web page?
Yeah, the processors are described on the wearcam.org site,
which describes the kind of computers that are used.
So, there's a variety of different processors.
The host is typically a Pentium-type processor.
Some of the other ones that are using a StrongRAM 1100
is the host processor that's got enough power to run Linux and X86.
Can you repeat the URL? We've got some people with some hands there.
We can have one try to look at what you would know.
Actually, when you get the video feed, I can show you.
Is there a Linux box there or something that can pick this up?
Because it was showing up earlier, I think, on a variety of Linux PCs
and it appeared as some kind of normal Unix box.
Yeah, we do have several boxes here.
The problem is that we're getting a denial-of-service attack
on a router that's streaming from this.
And so, we're not able to pass any traffic.
And so, that's what we're dealing with.
We've only got internal connectivity at the moment.
Let me take a couple more questions.
What about using this equipment in telepresence?
The question was, what about using this equipment in telepresence?
Well, in many ways, this is telepresence.
The question was, do you see this as a mass-market commodity type of technology?
I think it's going to take a few years to mass-produce this apparatus.
So, I see it maybe as a few years off before it becomes a commodity technology.
The question was, what is the status of PTP, the protocol you're using to transfer the images?
PTP is something that we're working on now, Picture Transfer Protocol.
So, there's a good chance we may end up deciding to run that over IPv6.
Or, we're looking also to do some embodiments with UDP.
And so, we have a working embodiment with PTP.
And so, we're just experimenting and further developing the protocol.
And also, the whole notion of sending the most updated images.
So, you understand, with video, if a packet is lost, then there is no sense.
So, what I suggested was that each packet be a picture, one packet be one picture.
And select the degree of JPEG compression that would make that possible.
So, rather than using an MPEG stream that would require previous or next images,
the idea is to have each packet be one frame of video.
And then, if and when a packet is lost, then rather than asking for a resend,
we simply get the next image that's most up-to-date.
Because the underlying assumption is that the camera or the device, especially iPad,
can pull out 100 frames a second out of an eye of wear.
And maybe you can only send 10 frames a second.
So, if one of those is lost, there will be invariably a newer image that wants to be sent.
Great. I've got a question from the guy in the back here.
The question is, does the eye-tap track your eye movements?
Some embodiments of it involve an eye-tracker, but not necessarily.
So, that's a separate feature that can be included or doesn't need to be included.
I wrote in a Linux journal early this month, early this year in March,
a Linux journal, I described the Reality Window Manager
and how the Window Manager can be made to work based on gaze patterns.
You look at windows in order to select them.
Apparently, we've got some connectivity, so we're going to try to restore your feed as soon as we can.
I'm going to take a few more questions here in the middle.
What is the frame rate that you see, Professor?
The frame rate that I internally get is adjustable.
I can choose to get the full frame rate on the order of 60 frames per second,
or I can also select a frame rate.
What I often do is I remotely log in to another computer
and then send it back to me so that I can see a frame rate that would be typical of a computer somewhere else.
So, a lot of times if I'm giving a lecture, say, in the UK somewhere,
I remotely log into the computer and then bring it back so that I get a kind of delayed experience
so that that enters into the feed, that loop of how I give the presentation.
The question was how much weight and how does this affect your range of movement, the equipment that you wear?
The major effect is, well, the equipment is much lighter now than 20 years ago.
It was a very heavy apparatus back in the 1970s, weighing some rigs, weighing as much as I did,
and now it's quite a bit lighter over the years.
So, I've built a number of them of different weights.
I've built more than 100 different units of very different weights.
Some of them are quite lightweight and have lesser capabilities.
A large, big old cluster, of course, you expect that to be heavier than, say, a simple video processor
matched with a single computer as its host capacity.
Professor, did you get that question?
The question was can you sort of enhance your senses, your vision, because you're me,
do things like binoculars or some kind of digital enhancement of your vision?
A couple of attributes of the current system.
One is that I can see in total darkness because of the infrared capability of the eye cap.
Another interesting effect, of course, is that you see a lot of things that are happening
over a broad band of frequencies, such as the elevator doors of all these sensor systems,
and you can see where all the lights are, and I could read the numbers on the chips
that were on the elevator door at the sides, so I would often, at first when I was wearing the eye cap,
I would often look at the open elevator door and would be reading the numbers on the chips
and commenting on the resistor values, and other people would say,
what are you talking about, I don't see anything.
And then I took off my glasses and I realized I couldn't see anything
except the black strip of plastic running down the side of the elevator,
and I was seeing right through it, because this was the device that was sensing
whether or not the door was blocked, and there was some 42 LEDs
and the circuit board running the whole length there.
So you can see a lot of things like that.
The other thing, of course, is the entertainment vision that I would typically see,
for example, when I'm doing flips on a wheel on a car that was going up 60 miles an hour,
I could still count the bolts on the bolt circle and read the writing on the tires,
because of the sort of entertainment effect that the eye cap can impart.
Is there an implementation of your window manager that you spoke of earlier?
There are some prototypes of the video orbits,
so, for example, now the video orbit is available on the webcam.org site.
Professor, we just got your feed.
We're getting your feed and we're queuing down the line,
so we're seeing what you're seeing.
Oh, excellent. What sort of frame rate are you getting?
It looks like about three to four frames a second,
maybe between two and four frames a second.
That's a little bit low now, I guess.
It's bursting. It's bursting sometimes and then sometimes slowing down.
I guess it probably depends on what kind of traffic we have out in the other room.
So what do you see now?
So this is the hallway at the University of Toronto,
and then this is the section of the lab that I'm in here,
so I'll just give you a little tour.
We have a little area here with chairs, tables and chairs,
And there are some various brochures here,
Can you see what you see now?
We love you. We love you, Professor.
You've definitely got another one's crew book, I think.
And what we have is a series of papers and brochures,
and there's a piece of recycling bin here
because we've got too much junk flying around,
so I'll just put that in my recycling bin here
to use some good for some cause here.
and I've got here on my door,
I've got this image, some examples of pictures that I've taken,
And the title of my talk here
Let's see if you can see that.
Yeah, DEF CON 7 to do headset extras,
The title of my talk is personal cybernetics,
and that's what I'm talking about here.
is this notion of personal cybernetic technology.
The combination of the Wear Comp Infection
these two devices when combined together
give you what I refer to as personal cybernetics.
And personal cybernetics provides a kind of framework
for a personal extension of the mind and body.
And the apparatus of the invention has evolved somewhat.
This is a picture of one of the early versions from years ago,
a very cumbersome sort of ITAP type,
that involves a cathode ray tube.
And through some degree of time error,
the ones involving cathode ray tubes until more recently,
what I have is this kind of eyeglass-based device
so that it just looks like ordinary eyeglasses,
and yet continues to provide an output
of at least one eye of the wearer.
So how is my video feed coming through?
I mean, the frame rate is, like I say,
it's still between probably two and five frames a second,
and we've got a really nice projector here
that's giving us a pretty good view.
We have some questions or some requests
that you, at some point, if you could stand in front of the mirror
so that we can see what you look like, if it's possible.
Yeah, I guess I could do that.
I've got some optics here in my lab, in my office.
I've got a first-person mirror here.
this is, I'm wearing now one of my older,
an older embodiment of my apparatus,
where I'll get a larger beam splitter.
This is a big beam splitter that I've got here,
and you can actually see through the beam splitter,
but if I hold it around this way,
it will function sort of like a mirror,
and you can kind of see.
So I use those beam splitters
I put a piece of glass into a bell jar
and pump all the air out of the glass,
and I have some electricity running through
a piece of aluminum wire inside the glass,
and it can deposit a thin layer of aluminum,
and then that makes a beam splitter,
and of course a beam splitter functions
like a partial mirror that reflects light
as long as there's nothing coming from the other side.
in some sense, I am a camera.
I would say I am a document camera,
so in many ways, people often make presentations
In this case, I am a document camera
in the sense that the eye cap is taking my right eye
and giving that effect as being a document camera,
and I could also say that I is a document camera.
The eye itself is functioning as a document camera,
and that's the general philosophy or framework
Now, earlier, a couple of people asked
about what are some of the evil,
and I guess maybe I should address that right away,
because one of the problems is,
what happens if this technology gets viruses?
So what happens if the operating system state
around this technology happens to be a virus
of some kind, an operating system,
that is a virus, or an operating system
a viral operating system as one
for which there is full disclosure
of its underlying principles of operation.
So what I define, in my own case,
is this notion of completely open
and I say, is the software kosher?
In other words, is it completely disclosed,
And viral is a broad sense of something
that doesn't come with a full disclosure,
and you can well imagine what would happen
if you had a machine around your body
and open to peer review and so on,
and some of the problems that might arise
spamming your real world body and so on.
So, can you hear me already?
Yeah, we're hearing you pretty well.
Occasionally you're getting some applause here,
and you sort of cut out,
but overall you're coming through pretty clear.
So the other application that I'm looking at
is filtering out spam in the real world.
One of the problems that I noticed
is that we've heard a lot lately
about spam in email and getting stammed,
but we've been stammed for years.
and advertisements that are posted upon us
With all this unwanted and unsolicited material,
and you see a big billboard that's spam.
So what I've been looking at
is ways to filter out spam.
Now, mainly spam has gotten a lot worse in recent years.
This is a picture of some spam
and it's located in a place
to ignore when it's located there.
and I've got my eyeglasses here.
People may have seen the newer ones,
which look just like ordinary glasses,
but they have this filtering out capability
this is what the spam looks like.
This spam is located right here.
It was in this building on the second floor
and what I've got here is,
you can see there is the urinal here,
and directly above it there is
and what you have is this cup
that's stuck under one cup of the bra,
to the particular task at hand.
The spam here has a caption under it
and this is the company logo here
and so on that we see within that spam,
and so the way that the spam is dealt with
is that the eyeglasses build an environment map
which collects all the images together
RWM is built upon this notion called video orbit,
and video orbit is based on
and video orbit assembles these images
and you can see here that the spam is here,
and the entire scene has been
Now once it's in that mathematical form,
then the spam can be replaced
where the spam has been filtered out.
is replace the spam with this waterfall image,
which is much more conducive to the task at hand.
So this device is something that I call a visual filter,
and the visual filter filters out spam
by virtue of a kill file,
so if you would like to get rid of something,
you press CTRL-K to enter that into your kill file,
and that pushes it up to the kill stack.
you can well envision a shared notion of kill files
so that you get these kill files.
Now I don't recognize that rudiment automatically,
instead it has to be attended at least once
to put it into your kill file,
but then at least you're not getting it again.
visual filter and reality window manager,
is defined in one of my favorite journals
this is the version of the Linux Journal
a second part of a two-part series
and the University of Toronto RWM Project.
And RWM is the reality window manager,
and that basically is the essence

And RWM is based on a framework

started in honor of Richard Dahlman,

a kind of software that is freely distributable
over some of the other possibilities
So RWM is based on the GNUx framework,

doesn't come with any viruses at all.

what we selected the Debian version

One aspect is called Shooting Back.
which, according to the Debian definition,

little badges with numbers on them.

and I look around this way
Yeah, we're able to see that.
and this is the camera here

I do not talk to strangers
that's what's written on this black card
so that when I walk into a department store
I do not talk to strangers
through the slot on my head
if you would like to talk to me
on my head will not be connected

so this is kind of in keeping

if you would like to try

and it sort of brings to life
really is, is get the other ITAP on at some point in time.
We'd love to have you back next year
and then show us what you're up to.
So that would be a great opportunity for you to do that.
Let me take another question here.
Do you agree at all that this technology should be used
Is it mainly important to have a wide vision of the world
How about, I got a question for you, professor.
I think I'm entitled to one since I'm announcing here.
What inspired you to get involved in this type of thing?
What kind of background did you have in this?
Why did you do this in the first place?
I guess my interest was in creating personal space.
I was a little bit disturbed by the way technology was going
and I didn't really like what I saw in terms of technology
and I decided, I guess, to create my own personal space.
The other motivation was kind of photographic in nature.
I've always been fascinated by light and photography
and I wanted to become a camera,
sort of being a camera as a very existential principle
of self-determination and mastery over one's own destiny.
So it's kind of a long story that I'll have to write one day.
Well, I want to thank you for joining us.
We've got a full house here.
That just kicked ass, I've got to say.
